articles.title: Alan Turing institute launches new mission to protect UK from cyber-attacks
articles.trailText: Programme is designed to defend energy, transport and utilities amid concern over vulnerability to internet outages
articles.summary: The Alan Turing Institute launched a mission to defend UK energy, transport and utilities from cyber-attacks and internet outages, refocusing the government-funded AI body after internal turmoil. After CEO Jean Innes resigned last month amid a staff revolt and ministerial pressure, chair Doug Gurr said 78 of the 440-staff institute’s research projects have been closed, spun out or completed to fit the new direction. ex-Air and Space Warfare Centre commander Blythe Crawford will report next month on supporting defence, national security and intelligence. Priorities: AI to forecast weather, oceans and sea ice for emergency planners; cut emissions in transport, manufacturing and infrastructure; and build digital heart twins. The shift follows an AWS outage and attacks disrupting Jaguar Land Rover, M&S and Co-op.

articles.title: Tech chiefs tell Trump to call off troops – will Firefox go ‘full AI’?
articles.trailText: In this week’s newsletter: Silicon Valley billionaires have a hotline to the US president. Plus, the head of Firefox talks AI-integrated browsers, and more
articles.summary: Mozilla’s Firefox GM Anthony Enzor-DeMeo weighs AI-first browsers as OpenAI’s ChatGPT Atlas, Microsoft Edge Copilot Mode, Google’s Chrome with Gemini, and Perplexity’s Comet embed agents for shopping, summarizing and search—raising privacy questions. Trump canceled a planned National Guard “surge” to San Francisco after calls from donors Jensen Huang and Marc Benioff; Benioff earlier urged deployment, then reversed. AWS outage traced to an empty DNS record in US-East-1 that automation failed to fix. Tinder now requires face scans for new US users (also in AU, Canada, India), expanding across Match apps, igniting safety-versus-privacy debate. Tech donors are also funding East Wing demolition for a Trump White House ballroom, underscoring access concerns.

articles.title: Amazon confirms plans to lay off 14,000 corporate workers as part of wave of cuts
articles.trailText: Retail giant, which is vying to reverse pandemic hiring spree, attempts to cut costs and slim down its operation
articles.summary: Amazon confirmed layoffs of 14,000 corporate staff, part of a broader cost-cutting push to unwind pandemic-era hiring. Earlier reports (Reuters/WSJ) suggested up to 30,000 corporate cuts, potentially its largest. Affected areas include HR (People Experience and Technology), devices and services, and operations; Fortune says up to 15% of HR roles could go. Amazon has 1.55m employees, ~350k corporate. SVP Beth Galetti cited de-layering and shifting resources to “big bets,” with more efficiency moves eyed in 2026. CEO Andy Jassy has warned AI agents and genAI will reduce headcount. Shares rose 1.2%. Managers were trained Monday; email notifications begin the next morning.

articles.title: Elon Musk launches encyclopedia ‘fact-checked’ by AI and aligning with rightwing views
articles.trailText: Grokipedia’s entries hew closely to conservative talking points, with some journalists already saying it contains inaccurate information
articles.summary: Elon Musk launched Grokipedia, an AI-written encyclopedia fact-checked by his chatbot Grok and pitched as a right-leaning alternative to Wikipedia, despite many entries citing Wikipedia. Lacking human editors, the project was suggested by Trump administration AI/crypto adviser David Sacks. Musk, who derides mainstream media and promotes X, has tuned Grokipedia to conservative narratives: its January 6 entry references widespread claims of voting irregularities, downplays Trump’s role, and questions casualty/intent accounts. Reporters already flag inaccuracies, e.g., asserting pornography worsened the AIDS epidemic. Context: Musk briefly led Trump’s DOGE cost-cutting drive until April; an August Gallup poll named him America’s most disliked public figure.

articles.title: ‘A good moment in time for us’: Firefox head on AI browsers and what’s next for the web
articles.trailText: After the release of a slew of other AI-integrated browsers, Anthony Enzor-DeMeo discusses ChatGPT Atlas, the Google monopoly trial – and the future
articles.summary: Firefox GM Anthony Enzor-DeMeo, reacting to OpenAI’s ChatGPT Atlas, Edge Copilot Mode, Chrome with Gemini and Perplexity’s Comet, says AI browsers’ 'answer-first' paradigm may not suit everyone; he values cited sources. He warns AI paywalls could close the web. Firefox will add optional AI but keep user choice: a neutral sidebar supporting Copilot, Gemini, Perplexity; privacy by default (no login, private browsing). Paid AI is ~3% globally; business models will vary by region. Mozilla partnered with Perplexity (terms undisclosed). On the Google antitrust ruling: search competition without harming independent engines was preserved. With 200m users, AI neutrality is a growth bet.

articles.title: More than a million people every week show suicidal intent when chatting with ChatGPT, OpenAI estimates
articles.trailText: Finding is one of most direct statements from the tech company on how AI can exacerbate mental health issues
articles.summary: OpenAI says >1m ChatGPT users weekly exhibit explicit suicidal planning/intent; 0.07% (~560k of 800m weekly users) show possible psychosis/mania signs. Calling it an initial, hard-to-measure analysis, the firm faces a lawsuit over a teen suicide and an FTC probe into chatbot harms to youth. OpenAI claims a GPT-5 update boosts safety: 91% compliant vs 77% for a previous GPT-5 in tests across >1,000 self-harm chats; 170 clinicians reviewed 1,800 responses, helped write guidance. Changes add crisis hotline surfacing and break reminders. Researchers warn about sycophancy; OpenAI denies causal links. Altman plans loosening content limits, incl. adult erotica.

articles.title: Ultra-HD televisions not noticeably better for typical viewer, scientists say
articles.trailText: Research shows 4K or 8K screens offer no distinguishable benefit over similarly sized 2K screen in average living room
articles.summary: Cambridge and Meta researchers report most viewers gain no visible sharpness from 4K/8K over 2K at typical living-room distances. In lab tests using a movable 27in 4K monitor, 18 participants distinguished one-pixel line patterns (black-white, red-green, yellow-violet) from grey to find the eye’s resolution limit; 12 also judged text sharpness. Average acuity exceeded 20/20 (60 PPD): 94 PPD greyscale, 89 PPD red/green, 53 PPD yellow/violet; text matched line results. A chart and free calculator map screen size and viewing distance to required resolution. Example: a 44in 4K TV at 2.5m already exceeds acuity—8K won’t look sharper. Published in Nature Communications.

articles.title: Apple Watch Ultra 3 review: the biggest and best smartwatch for an iPhone
articles.trailText: Third-gen watch adds 5G, satellite SOS and messaging, a bigger screen and longer battery life in same rugged design
articles.summary: Apple Watch Ultra 3: £749/€899/$799 rugged 49mm titanium iPhone-only smartwatch adds 5G, satellite SOS, and US/Canada/Mexico satellite messaging (plan required). Bigger, brighter sapphire display with slimmer bezels; S10 chip; double‑tap and wrist‑flick gestures. 6% larger battery lasts 3+ days (50% in 30min; full ~2h), but short of Garmin week-long rivals. watchOS 26 adds Waypoint face. Dual‑band GPS now class‑leading; wait-for-GPS‑lock action button; 11–14h high-accuracy tracking. Strong health suite (ECG, SpO2, hypertension alerts, sleep score) plus running power/dynamics, cycling/swim/triathlon, dive to 40m. 100m water resistance, UWB. Best Apple Watch, modest upgrade.

articles.title: ‘People thought I was a communist doing this as a non-profit’: is Wikipedia’s Jimmy Wales the last decent tech baron?
articles.trailText: In an online landscape characterised by doom and division, the people’s encyclopedia stands out – a huge collective endeavour giving everyone free access to the sum of human knowledge. But with Elon Musk branding it ‘Wokipedia’ and AI looming large, can it survive?
articles.summary: Wikipedia, which turns 25 in January, grew from Jimmy Wales's pivot from the slow, expert-only Nupedia after a 2000 family medical scare. Now >7m English articles and 18 languages with >1m each, it underpins the web. Wales's book, The Seven Rules of Trust, touts Wikipedia's formula: clear purpose, neutrality, civility and radical transparency. He rejects Elon Musk's "Wokipedia" attacks and "Grokipedia" pitch, denies political capture, and defends DEI grants as mission-critical to global coverage. He sees authoritarian censorship (China bans; Russia sporadic blocks) as a bigger threat than AI. Donations fund tech, ops and grants. A capitalist by instinct, Wales also runs Fandom (TPG-owned), and urges platforms to "show your work," not chase outrage.

articles.title: US and China reach ‘final deal’ on TikTok sale, treasury secretary says
articles.trailText: Scott Bessent said plan was part of framework for trade deal but did not share details on transferring app’s ownership
articles.summary: US treasury secretary Scott Bessent said Washington and Beijing finalized a $14bn deal to transfer TikTok’s US operations, to be sealed by Trump and Xi in Korea on Thursday, and that China approved it. Under Trump’s 25 Sept order, US/international investors would own ~65%, ByteDance/Chinese <20%, control the algorithm, and hold 6 of 7 board seats. Prospective backers include Rupert Murdoch and Larry Ellison; Barron Trump has been floated. The agreement sits within a broader trade framework preceding talks on soy purchases, trade balance, and fentanyl-linked 20% tariffs. The 2024 statutory ban’s January 2025 deadline was extended four times as talks progressed.

articles.title: Could the internet go offline? Inside the fragile system holding the modern world together
articles.trailText: Behind every meme and message is creaking, decades-old infrastructure. Internet experts can think of scenarios that could bring it all crashing down …
articles.summary: Could the internet go offline? Concentrated, aging infrastructure could cascade into the “big one”: tornado wipes Google us-central1 (Council Bluffs); heatwave cripples AWS US East-1; an AI-introduced AWS bug amplifies traffic reroutes. Result: Signal, Slack, Netflix, Lloyd’s, IoT fail, though routing persists, says Doug Madory. Undersea cable cuts rarely decisive (150–200 faults/year). True catastrophe targets DNS/BGP: Verisign (.com) failure, BIND or BGP bugs—Dyn 2016 is a cautionary tale. Restarting would be uncertain, notes Steven Murdoch; UK had a meet-in-a-pub contingency. DNS engineer Michał Woźniak says two devices and a router still constitute “the internet”. Cloud giants hold >60% share.

articles.title: Fare game: what the battle between taxis and Uber means for your airport trip in Sydney and Melbourne
articles.trailText: Taxi companies are trialling flat-fare rides to challenge Uber’s dominance on the airport run. Can they win back support – or at least customers?
articles.summary: Melbourne and Sydney airports are testing taxi pricing to claw back riders from Uber. Melbourne has kiosks at Qantas domestic offering fixed fares via 13Cabs tech, dispatching Silver Service, Black & White, 13Cabs or Silver Top. Sydney launches a 12‑month $60 flat fare ($80 Maxi) to the CBD on 3 November. Meanwhile, Uber Pin pickups are permanent at Sydney international and run at Melbourne, lifting share: Sydney international Uber rose from 35% (2019) to 50% (2024) and 73% this year; Melbourne: Uber 60%, taxis 20%. Taxi industry calls Uber Pin anticompetitive; minister cites choice. Price checks: Melbourne taxi $78–$79 vs Uber $57–$65; Sydney taxi $60 vs Uber $45–$66.
